Name: Brianna
Description: Meet Brianna ‚Äî the sweetheart with the cutest Yoda ears! Brianna is a total lovebug who melts hearts wherever she goes. She‚Äôs friendly, affectionate, and always ready for an adventure. Whether it‚Äôs a leisurely walk or a cozy night in, Brianna‚Äôs happiest just being by your side. This resilient girl was found as a stray in New York with multiple large abdominal masses; she desperately needed medical care that the municipal shelter couldn‚Äôt provide. Thankfully, she got her second chance with us and is now healthy, healing, and overflowing with gratitude and love. Brianna deserves her happily ever after. If you‚Äôre looking for a loyal, gentle, and joyful companion with the most adorable Yoda ears, Brianna is your girl. Apply to adopt Brianna today and give her the forever home she‚Äôs been waiting for! All dogs will be altered, microchipped, and receive age-appropriate vaccines prior to adoption. Name: Emoji
Description: Hi! I just arrived! My foster pawrents are getting to know me and will add more info soon. Put Short Bio here: Emoji is a fun loving and adventurous pup! He's got a lot of energy which he burns off by running and chasing his ball and playing with his toys. He's mastered sit and is almost completely potty trained. He's very social loves meeting new people and is interested and likes other dogs! Fill out all below: Personality & Characteristics: spunky, energetic, sweet My foster dog is good with: (Dogs, Kids) My foster dog is: house trained Energy Level (1= calm, 10= high energy): 6 Barker? Or Quiet Pup?: quiet only barks at his toys occasionally Appetite: loves food! 3 meals a day Favorite Things: balls, toys, exploring Commands/Tricks: sit, wait ALL adoptions require a completed application and final contract. The application can be found at WaldosRescue.org and once you are approved to adopt you will be put in touch with the foster to see if it‚Äôs a good match. We are a RESCUE not a shelter. We conduct veterinary and personal reference checks during the application approval process. We are unable to contact every applicant for every dog. We will select the best applicant for each dog, based on the dogs needs. Waldos Rescue Pen is a 501c3 whose primary focus is rescuing dogs from the euthanasia list from high kill shelters throughout the United States and Korea.

Name: Amped
Description: Say hi to Amped! Loyal, sweet, and energetic pup. When we first picked him up, he walked right up to us with his tail wagging ready to go home. He went straight into the back seat of the car and took a quiet nap on his hour drive to his temporary home. He warmed up to our family very quickly and likes to check in on us when we go into separate rooms to make sure everything is okay. He's becoming a pro at being in his crate when we are not home and when he uses it to sleep some nights he gives no fuss and quietly sleeps. He is the best pup at using the bathroom outside and has had zero accidents in the house! He is learning to walk slowly and steady on his leash while he takes in all the new sites and scents. Although he is very playful he is equally a snuggler/napper. With some training and lots of love, I guarantee that Amped (aka Ranger) will be the best companion. My foster dog is good with: Dogs (not tested with kids or cats) My foster dog is: Crate trained, house trained, Low shed 3 Keywords for your pup: Loyal, Loving, Playful Energy Level (1 = calm, 10 = high energy): 6 Barker? Or Quiet Pup?: Barks at the door and unfamilar sounds Walking Manners: Learning quickly, already improving on leash Appetite: Mealtime is his favorite. Favorite Things: Mealtime, snuggles, playtime (especially tug of war). Commands/Tricks: Knows ‚Äúsit,‚Äù "lay down", learning ‚Äústay‚Äù, ‚Äúcome‚Äù, and "give me paw" ALL adoptions require a completed application and final contract. Name: Pepper
Description: Pepper is the sweetest, most loving boy. He spent his first two years in a happy home with kids after being adopted through Waldo‚Äôs, but his owner sadly lost his job and home and can no longer keep him. Pepper loves going on walks and runs and gets an A++ for eating. He‚Äôs potty trained and rarely has accidents, though he‚Äôs still working on keeping up his good habits in a new home. He loves being petted and gets so excited when it‚Äôs time to go outside. He‚Äôs playful, gentle, and such a good boy in the house. Pepper has so much love to give and will make the sweetest, happiest companion.

Name: Baby Miami
Description: Meet Miami ‚Äî the sunshine girl with a heart full of love! Once a stray in Florida, Baby Miami ended up in a shelter that sadly didn‚Äôt have the resources to care for her. Her life was at risk, so we stepped in and brought her all the way to New York. It may not be the palm-tree paradise she came from, but Miami is thriving in the big city. This sweet girl has adorable puppy energy, loves to cuddle, and is completely unaware of her own size, which only makes her more lovable. Miami is a good girl through and through, and she‚Äôs ready to shower her forever family with joy and affection. If you‚Äôre looking for a happy-hearted, cuddly companion who radiates sunshine wherever she goes, Miami is your girl. All dogs will be altered, microchipped, and receive age-appropriate vaccines prior to adoption. Name: Dogberry (Berry)
Description: I‚Äôm a lovable young pup with a shiny black coat and an even brighter personality. I‚Äôm curious, excited, and full of energy‚Äî the perfect adventure buddy. Personality & Characteristics: Sweet, social, and smart! I love being near my humans, exploring new things, frolicking in the rain, running and chasing and most of all - soaking up affection and love. I‚Äôm still learning some manners, but I‚Äôm picking them up quickly. Berry Videos Good with: ‚úÖ Dogs | ‚úÖ Kids | ‚ùì Cats (not tested yet) I‚Äôm: üê∂ Crate trained | üöΩ Working on house training | üñ§ Low shed 3 Keywords for your pup: Playful ¬∑ Affectionate ¬∑ Loyal Energy Level (1= calm, 10= high energy): 7 (enough pep for fun walks and playtime, but loves naps too!) Barker? Or Quiet Pup?: Barker (mainly to alert of potty time and looking for attention) Walking Manners: Very good, and getting better every day! I love walks and respond well to gentle guidance on leash. Great on elevators and with greeting others. Loves meeting new people and pups. A little timid of all of the new sights and sounds, will pause to take in new surroundings but no barking and will continue walk without any assistance. Appetite: Big fan of mealtime ‚Äî food is my love language. Favorite Things: Enrichment toys (like a Kong), running, walks. Commands/Tricks: working on commands but a great 'sitter' in public. Name: Holly Jolly
Description: Holly Jolly lives up to her name. She is a bubbly, energetic and friendly girl who always has something to wag her tail about. She loves her long walks and will cozy up beside you when she is at home in between. She is respectful of your things and is completely house broken. She loves people and will try to snuggle up with everyone! She loves her food and is an extremely good leaner/listener as she responds to things like wait, sit, stay, no, and leave it. Name: Doris
Description: Doris - 1 year, 18lbs, Corgi/Beagle Mix, Spayed This dog is eligible to join our foster-to-adopt program. Please email fostertoadopt@socialteesnyc.org with the animal‚Äôs name in the subject line if you are interested! Want to straight up adopt? Submit an adoption application a t socialteesnyc.org Level of dog ownership experience needed: BEGINNER: This means we predict this dog will be low on the challenge scale due to its breed/age combo. Potentially a good fit for someone who has relevant dog care experience (fostering, dog sitting) and is looking to adopt their first pup. Energy level MEDIUM: Needs a daily 60 walk or window of quick paced exercise (minimum) in addition to potty break strolls (10-30 min each). Also needs significant socializing opportunities outside the home and mental stimulation at home like tricks training practice, chew items, and puzzle toys. (This is regardless of dog size ‚Äì many small breeds were designed for lots of activity and will exhibit unwanted behavior when they‚Äôre understimulated.) Okay in the city? We don‚Äôt know yet. Most adult dogs do well in the city after they‚Äôve had time to adjust to a new environment, but some never adapt and need homes in the burbs. Potty trained? Probably! Adults usually are, but all will have transitional accidents for the first week or so. A consistent walking route and schedule plus finding spots with grass or dirt can help. Social with other dogs? Yes, but we don‚Äôt know to what degree yet. Some like to wrestle with every passing pup, others can coexist well but prefer to keep to themselves. We‚Äôll learn more soon. Social with cats? Not sure yet! Some breed mixes that are generally NOT great matches for homes with cats include large hounds, huskies, and shepherds. Comfortable with children? (ALWAYS requires adult supervision) We‚Äôre not sure yet, but we try to err on the side of caution. Respectful kids ages 8 and up are probably a safe bet. Children must always be monitored and taught to interact with dogs of any age respectfully. Medical status Healthy as far as we know. Up to date on their DHPP, Bordetella, and Rabies vaccines; heartworm tested if coming from the South or Puerto Rico ; spayed/neutered; microchipped; treated with dewormer upon intake How this dog ended up with Social Tees: Most of our dogs come via partner groups who help us save them from shelters where they are at risk of euthanasia in Tennessee, Los Angeles and Puerto Rico. There are very few spay/neuter resources there and many more animals in those areas than there are people to adopt them. Rescue groups like ours bring them to the northeast where the desire for pets like these allows us to save their lives. PLEASE NOTE: We cannot guarantee any breed mix, exact age, or full grown size (if the dog is under a year old). We do our best with very educated guesses though! This animal is not at the Social Tees office, all are in foster homes. LEARN MORE ABOUT US: socialteesnyc.org and Instagram @socialteesnyc

Name: Wilson
Description: Name: Wilson Age: 9 years old Weight: 75 lbs Breed: American bulldog Mix ‚∏ª Senior gentleman Wilson has had an unpredictable home for most of his life. He ended up in the shelter a few times because his owner could not take care of him, but he was always eventually reclaimed. When his owner was evicted in September, Wilson and his feline sibling were left behind, trapped in their apartment. Thankfully they were rescued, but for Wilson it was the start of a difficult few months. Back in the city shelter once again, Wilson slowly started to shut down, becoming more anxious everyday, eventually refusing to go on walks, interact with staff and barely eating. In November, Wilson was moved to the euthanasia list and his time was running out. Thankfully, at the last minute a kind hearted foster came forward and agreed to take in this gentle giant so we were able to welcome him to our rescue. Wilson was a little nervous at all the changes, but after a few days of love and attention in a home with 2 cats and a small dog, Wilson relaxed and showed us what an amazing addition to any family he would. Wilson is a happy, playful guy who adores spending time with his people. He doesn‚Äôt need to sleep in the bed with you but he would love to curl up in a dog bed right beside you at night. He doesn‚Äôt need to be entertained when you want a quiet evening but he would love to snuggle on the couch with you. He doesn‚Äôt need you to take him hiking every weekend but he would love a game of fetch at the park. Wilson is cat, dog and kid friendly, but he is a big boy who will need a playdate with dogs and kids before deciding if he is the right match for you. Wilson had some issues with his teeth when he first came to us but has had a full dental and is now in much better shape. He does have some teeth missing and would do well with softer food and treats. If you think you can give Wilson all the love he deserves and would like to meet him, please go to Petstablished.com or follow the link below to complete an application to adopt. All of our animals are in foster homes. For the sake of our animals and foster families, you must have an approved application with references before you can meet them. http://shelterchic.org/adopt/ In order to receive a speedy response to any inquiry, please email us directly at Info@ShelterChic.org or check out our website ShelterChic.org where you will find the answer to most questions about our adoption process and fees. Please remember that our organization is run entirely by volunteers in our spare time, and emails are responded to in order of importance. If you do not hear from us and cannot find the information needed on our website or in our animals profile, please reach out to us again. For more images and tales of our pets in foster-care check out our social media pages @shelterchic and @shelterchicanimals

Name: Jackrabbit
Description: Meet Jackrabbit ‚Äì Your Next Adventure Buddy! üêæ Smart, curious, and always ready to explore‚Äî Jackrabbit is the total package. Once a stray in Mississippi, this outdoorsy pup has blossomed into a confident, enrichment-loving explorer who‚Äôs just waiting for the right person to share life‚Äôs journey with. Whether it‚Äôs a hike through the woods, a stroll through the neighborhood, or learning new tricks, Jackrabbit is eager, attentive, and ready to be your loyal sidekick. He thrives on stimulation, loves being part of the action, and will make every day a little more exciting. Name: Daisy
Description: Playful, love-bug Daisy is a 55lbs, 1 year old, female mix breed dog looking for a home with lots of love to share. Daisy is the perfect family dog, good with other dogs, cats and people of all ages. Daisy loves to be a part of the action whatever you‚Äôre doing. Cuddling on the couch, walks in the park, a car trip‚Ä¶every activity is her idea of good time. Daisy recently had surgery on her hind leg to fix a tear on her CCL (doggy version of an ACL) which caused her knee cap to move out of place. We are unsure what caused the injury, but she is healing very well and should make a full recovery. She is a high energy dog who would be happy in almost any household, but she would love a family who will continue this smart girls training, take her on long walks around the neighborhood, and if there are other pets in the home, Daisy would love a playmate. Daisy still has lots of puppy energy and personality, she will need an adopter who is willing to her become the perfect family member. Name: Mims
Description: Name: Mims Age: 10 - 12 years old Weight: 55 lbs Breed: Labrador Terrier Mix Sweet Mims was surrendered at the kill shelter when her owner decided her health concerns were too much trouble to deal with and asked that she be euthanized. Thankfully, Mims showed everyone she met what a complete sweetheart she is and the shelter reached out to us to see if we could nurse her back to health and give her a second chance at a loving home. Mims is a staff favorite who has a long list of hobbies! ‚Ä¢ she likes cuddling. ‚Ä¢ she loves to nap on the couch although she‚Äôs reluctant to climb up without encouragement. (it seems possible she was not allowed on furniture) ‚Ä¢ she loves a bit of tug and settling in with her popcorn üçø toy for a good chew ‚Ä¢ she loves all people. She‚Äôs incredibly friendly and gentle with people. ‚Ä¢ she loves little walks ‚Ä¢ she‚Äôs great at the vets office ‚Ä¢ she loves sun bathing and rolling in the grass ‚Ä¢ she‚Äôs great in the car Mims would do best in an adult only home or with older children. She does not get on well with other animals. Mims is listed as special needs due to her health concerns, please find her on our social media pages to see how far shes come. Mims is looking for a loving retirement home to give her all the love she has missed out on so far. Name: Tyler
Description: Name: Tyler Age: 15 years old Weight: 16 lbs Breed: Chihuahua Mix ‚∏ª Senior Chihuahua Tyler, who we pulled from ACC in July, is still looking for his forever home! Tyler loves to spend time outside and would be delighted to have access to a garden for sunbathing. Tyler is happy to be around other dogs as long as they are a similar energy level to him - buddy‚Äôs who like to nap! He is not looking for a playmate and prefers to be left to his own devices. Tyler loves car rides but is also quite happy to stay at home and has no seperation anxiety. Similarly, Tyler will be ok around cats who leave him alone, but will bark if they come too close. Tyler enjoys spending time with his human family, he is the most adorable compainion, but he can get nervous around strangers. Due to his age, Tyler would do best in an adult only home or with older children. Tyler has the early signs of canine dementia, so he needs someone willing to keep an eye on him if he starts to become confused or anxious. He needs someone who understands it will take him a while to understand new situations and will be patient when he needs time to adjust. Please consider opening your heart and home to give this sweetheart his perfect retirement home ‚ù§Ô∏è If you think you can give Tyler all the love he deserves and would like to meet him, please go to Petstablished.com or follow the link below to complete an application to adopt. Name: Jimmy
Description: ‚ÄúMeet King James, a charming and affectionate five-year-old pup who‚Äôs truly as majestic as his name suggests. This sweet, handsome boy was on the list to be euthanized and we were fortunate enough to save him minutes before it was too late . Surrendered through no fault of his own, King Jimmy was deeply loved by his previous family, who made the difficult decision to rehome him after moving in to care for elderly parents. This loyal boy has known nothing but love and kindness and is now hoping to find his next forever home‚Äîone where he can once again be someone‚Äôs best friend, hiking buddy, and devoted shadow. King aka Jimmy is the perfect blend of playful and chill. He's housebroken, crate trained, and knows all his basic commands‚Äîincluding ‚Äúsit,‚Äù ‚Äústay,‚Äù ‚Äúwait,‚Äù and ‚Äúleave it.‚Äù He‚Äôs got great leash manners, walking at a calm, easy pace with only the occasional tug when something especially exciting (like a stray cat!) crosses his path. He‚Äôs easily redirected with a gentle voice or treat and always eager to please. Speaking of treats, he loves them :) Jimmy‚Äôs previous owner stated that he was attacked by two dogs before coming into the shelter (see his adorably wonky ear). He‚Äôs been getting along great with the dogs he‚Äôs met in foster, but if you have another dog a meet and greet is required to make sure it‚Äôs a good match. Jimmy loves to play with his toys and would be great with older kids. He would make a wonderful addition to a lucky family To see Jimmy's full profile with more pictures, please visit wagtopia.com

Name: Rocky
Description: Meet Rocky, a resilient and affectionate 4.5-year-old pup looking for a fresh start after a tough few months of transitions. Originally rehomed by his first owner, Rocky was then surrendered by his second family after just three months, through no fault of his own. Despite the instability in his life, Rocky remains a sweet, wiggly boy who greets everyone with a wagging tail and a heart full of love. Rocky is the definition of a social butterfly‚Äîhe's incredibly people-friendly, happily nuzzling into volunteers and seeking out affection wherever he goes. He allows all-over handling, even during medical care, and has proven himself to be both gentle and trusting as he heals from some minor wounds. Though he can be a little snatchy with treats, he's food-motivated and easy to redirect. On walks, Rocky pulls only slightly and enjoys sniffing and exploring. He loves being outside and is eager to get out of his kennel, though he sometimes needs a little coaxing to go back in. In playgroups, Rocky has shown some curiosity about other dogs but tends to be more of an observer, keeping his distance and sniffing around the yard rather than engaging in direct play. He‚Äôs also lived with cats in his previous home and reportedly got along well with them. Whether you‚Äôre looking for a loyal companion to share quiet walks, cuddle sessions, or just some relaxed company, Rocky could be your guy. Complete an application for adoption today.

Name: Brandi
Description: Pretty girl Brandy, 50 lbs, 2-5 years old is a total lover and she is happiest just to be in your company. She has a lot of puppy energy and is looking for a family interested in playing, training and spending lots of time with her. She loves people and greets everyone with her whole body happy wiggle. Before coming to our rescue, Brandi spent 5 months at the city shelter after being found as a stray. Brandi adjusted well in her foster home, she is house broken and in good health apart from some seasonal allergies. Brandi does sometimes get nervous around loud, unexpected noises and would be happier living in a quieter home. She has done well meeting other dogs and cats but since her previous living situation is unknown to us, she will need to meet any other pets in your home. She has been great with all the people she has met but might be too playful for very small children. If you think you can give Brandi all the love she deserves and would like to meet her, please go to Petstablished.com or follow the link below to complete an application to adopt. Name: Charlie
Description: Charlie - 10 months & 50lbs (as of 8/12/25) Pointer Mix Neutered Expected to be about 50lbs Full Grown Our Team Says: Charlie needs a home in the burbs. He REALLY loves other dogs and would do really well in a home with another pup :) This puppy is eligible to join our foster-to-adopt program. Please email fostertoadopt@socialteesnyc.org with the animal‚Äôs name in the subject line if you are interested! Want to straight up adopt? Submit an adoption application at socialteesnyc.org. Thier Foster Parent Says: "Charlie is an incredibly sweet, loving, funny guy. He loves to play with toys and other dogs, and, like most young dogs his age, likes to pass out after he's exhausted himself from playtime. He also loves to snuggle when he's tired, resting his head on your shoulder while he nestles. He is VERY scared of loud or new noises so he does need help shifting energy when he gets startled like that. Sometimes he barks and does a low-level growl when he hears those unfamiliar noises but he is never aggressive towards others. The only time he really barks is if someone is approaching the house to alert us but then quickly goes to hide if someone new comes inside. He can get a little scared and hide but, as he gets more and more acclimated, he comes out to explore his surroundings. It's very important to instill in him that he is safe and cared for at all times. Once he has decided you are a safe person, he will be your shadow! He's very playful and likes to jump up and sometimes will accidentally scratch but it's never on purpose-he just loves to have fun! He gets up around 7:00 am to go outside and have breakfast and then sometimes will even go back to sleep. Then he likes to play with other dogs (we have 2 others in the house) before taking a nap. We go for walks with Charlie to improve his leash etiquette-he's VERY eager to walk but is still learning how to walk better on the leash! Then we'll have dinner around 6:00 pm with him, he'll do some more romping, and he'll go to bed with us. He is very good about bedtime routine. Once the lights are off he goes to sleep and loves to cuddle up at the end of the bed. Overall, Charlie has been a real joy to have and to take care of. Anyone would be lucky to have him!" Level of dog ownership experience needed: INTERMEDIATE: As an adult, this dog will need significant structure and plenty of daily exercise, training, and mental stimulation ‚Äì 90 consecutive minutes of movement in the morning plus potty break walks and brain games throughout the day. The adopter must have relevant primary care experience with a similar breed, temperament, and/or energy level. (Primary care experience includes ownership, fostering, or dog sitting as an adult, not a dog you grew up with.) Relevant puppy care experience is a huge plus, but bare minimum the adopter must have TONS of time and patience. Raising a puppy can be a lot of fun, but it‚Äôs also tremendous work. Puppies‚Äô personalities and exercise/stimulation requirements change dramatically between now and when they‚Äôre a year old as their bodies and brains develop, so an active lifestyle and the ability to adapt to a pup‚Äôs evolving needs are a must. We strongly urge professional dog training with a rewards based trainer from the get go. Adults only or kids ages 8 and up ‚Äì all puppies go through a mouthy, rambunctious phase and often accidentally hurt children when playing. PLEASE DO YOUR OWN BREED RESEARCH to make sure you have a better understanding of the kind of temperament and exercise requirements this dog may have as an adult. Energy level MEDIUM: Very young puppies sleep and nap a lot, but their energy level skyrockets when they become teens (4 months to around a year). As an adult, this dog will need significant structure and plenty of daily exercise, training, and mental stimulation ‚Äì 90 consecutive minutes of movement in the morning plus potty break walks and brain games throughout the day at a minimum. (This is regardless of dog size ‚Äì many small breeds were designed for lots of activity and will exhibit unwanted behavior when they‚Äôre understimulated.) Cuddle Bug Level-high Comfy with strangers?- Fine with meeting new people but not particularly interested, kind of shy in busy social situations like a gathering or a packed day in the park. Once he is inside he will shower them with kisses. He just needs to be in his safe space. Good with Children? (ALWAYS requires supervision)- Yes for 12 and up -- may be a little energetic or a little skittish, best with older children that can be extra gentle or that are big enough not to get accidentally knocked down Good with Other Dogs?- Yes -- Good with all other dogs (sizes, breeds, etc.) as far as we know and enjoys socializing with other canines Mouthy Behavior?- Is either still in the puppy stage or was never trained to not be mouthy. Wants to put everything in their mouth. Tries to chew on your hands when playing or needs attention, grabs the leash with its mouth, loves to gnaw on your personal belongings. He is easily corrected with a toy. Leash Manners?- Getting the Hang of it ‚Äì Probably hasn‚Äôt been on a leash much in its life but he is figuring it out. Might be a mild puller but responds to correction. Okay in the city? Sort of -- Spooked easily by loud noises and bustling areas but walks pretty well and probably just needs more time to adjust (may be a puppy or a brand new rescue) Jumping on People to Say Hi?- Medium ‚Äì Jumps up only on people the dog knows when really excited. Stops with correction. Separation Anxiety? -Low ‚Äì Completely fine being left home alone. Doesn‚Äôt cry or do anything shitty when you leave the apartment or house. Crate training? -Yep/mostly ‚Äì Seems comfortable in the crate, may whine a little at first but settles pretty quickly. We use the crate when we leave the pup alone and/or at night Medical status: Healthy as far as we know. Up to date on their DHPP and Bordetella vaccines (for dogs under 4 months old, adopters will need to finish the DHPP vaccine series and administer the Rabies vaccine at 16 weeks of age), spayed/neutered; microchipped; treated with dewormer upon How this dog ended up with Social Tees: Most of our dogs come via partner groups who help us save them from shelters where they are at risk of euthanasia in Tennessee or St. Thomas. There are very few spay/neuter resources there and many more animals in those areas than there are people to adopt them. Rescue groups like ours bring them to the northeast where the desire for pets like these allows us to save their lives. PLEASE NOTE: We cannot guarantee any breed mix, exact age, or full grown size (if the dog is under a year old). We do our best with very educated guesses though! This animal is not at the Social Tees office, all are in foster homes. LEARN MORE ABOUT US: socialteesnyc.org and Instagram @socialteesnyc

Name: Steve
Description: Steve - 1 year, 25lbs, BeagleTerrier Mix, Neutered - low rider :) This dog is eligible to join our foster-to-adopt program. Please email fostertoadopt@socialteesnyc.org with the animal‚Äôs name in the subject line if you are interested! Want to straight up adopt? Submit an adoption application a t socialteesnyc.org Their Foster Parent Says: " Steve loves people and dogs and chasing after squirrels and birds. Every time we pass a person or a dog, he is always wagging his tail and pulling his leash to greet them. As soon as someone gives him affection, he literally slides down and rolls over on his back for belly rubs. He is such a trusting and sweet dog. In the morning, he waits patiently for me in the bathroom while I get ready and will sit or lay down on my bath mat (since I have towels everywhere on the floor to protect my white carpets, he thinks any towel is for him) then we go for a 45 minute walk, come home and he eats his breakfast, depending on how tired he is from his walk, he will typically play on his own for an hour before taking a 4 hour nap. We then go for a potty break, play a little more and then another 45 minute walk in the evening followed by dinner, more play time and a final night potty. He is definitely teething right now and is a little mouthy which is understandable for a pup his age. He loves playing fetch, gnawing on his toys and is very food motivated. As a typical lab, he scarfs down his food in 5 minutes even with a slow feeder. He needs leash training as he pulls very hard during our walks when he sees a bird, squirrel or dog which is often as you can imagine in NYC. He is a little afraid of bikes, buses and leaf blowers and will pull the leash to move away from them and gets down low. However he is pretty tolerable of the city life and will adjust quickly. He‚Äôs very comfortable in elevators, with stairs and riding the subway which is impressive coming from South Carolina. The best part about this pup, is he practically came potty trained and crate trained and has had no accidents thus far! The best pup of the 7 I‚Äôve fostered thus far." Level of dog ownership experience needed: BEGINNER: This means we predict this dog will be low on the challenge scale due to its breed/age combo. Potentially a good fit for someone who has relevant dog care experience (fostering, dog sitting) and is looking to adopt their first pup. Energy level MEDIUM: Needs a daily 60-90 minute walk or window of quick paced exercise (minimum) in addition to potty break strolls (10-30 min each). Also needs significant socializing opportunities outside the home and mental stimulation at home like tricks training practice, chew items, and puzzle toys. (This is regardless of dog size ‚Äì many small breeds were designed for lots of activity and will exhibit unwanted behavior when they‚Äôre understimulated.) City pup Seems unfazed by the sights and sounds, may as well have been born here. POTTY TRAINING Yes ‚Äì Few or no accidents COMFORT LEVEL WITH STRANGERS Social butterfly ‚Äì Wants to be friends with everyone who walks by, loves anyone who will stop to say hello. BEHAVIOR WITH CHILDREN (always requires adult supervision) Maybe for age 12 and up ‚Äì Is either big and energetic (okay with kids big enough not to get knocked down) or a little skittish (could be comfortable with older children that can be extra gentle) SOCIAL BEHAVIOR WITH OTHER DOGS Yes ‚Äì Good with most other dogs (sizes, breeds, etc.) as far as we know and enjoys socializing with other canines RESPECTFUL BEHAVIOR WITH OTHER ANIMALS (cats, small pets, etc. Not sure ‚Äì Wants to chase squirrels and birds so may not be a good match for a home with cats, rabbits, etc. MOUTHY BEHAVIOR Needs training ‚Äì Is either still in the puppy stage or was never trained. Tries to put their mouth on your hands when playing or needs attention, grabs leash, chews on your personal belongings SEPARATION ANXIETY ( Adjusting ‚Äì Might cry for a few minutes when you first leave the house but settles pretty quickly and has no problem being left alone otherwise. LEASH MANNERS WTF is a leash ‚Äì Pulls hard. Zig zags like crazy. Has no idea how to walk on a leash or doesn‚Äôt have outside privileges yet (too young) CUDDLE BUG LEVEL Medium ‚Äì Likes to snuggle when he's in the mood but often stays in his own bed JUMPING ON PEOPLE TO SAY HELLO Needs training ‚Äì Very excited to greet everyone and has no idea how to do so politely. Jumps up on most strangers or other dogs that go by. In puppy phase or wasn‚Äôt trained as a young adult. CRATE TRAINING Yep/mostly ‚Äì Seems comfortable in the crate, may whine a little at first but settles pretty quickly. We use the crate when we leave the pup alone and/or at night. Medical status Healthy as far as we know. Up to date on their DHPP, Bordetella, and Rabies vaccines; heartworm tested if coming from the South or Puerto Rico ; spayed/neutered; microchipped; treated with dewormer upon intake How this dog ended up with Social Tees: Most of our dogs come via partner groups who help us save them from shelters where they are at risk of euthanasia in Tennessee, Los Angeles and Puerto Rico. There are very few spay/neuter resources there and many more animals in those areas than there are people to adopt them. Rescue groups like ours bring them to the northeast where the desire for pets like these allows us to save their lives. PLEASE NOTE: We cannot guarantee any breed mix, exact age, or full grown size (if the dog is under a year old). We do our best with very educated guesses though! This animal is not at the Social Tees office, all are in foster homes. LEARN MORE ABOUT US: socialteesnyc.org and Instagram @socialteesnyc

Name: Whitney
Description: **Meet Whitney: The Sweet and Gentle Soul** Introducing Whitney, the sweet and delicate sister of Wilbur and Wesley, who is ready to find her forever home! With her stunning blue eyes that shine with warmth and a gentle spirit, Whitney is a special pup who brings a touch of grace wherever she goes. Expected to grow to around 40 pounds, she is the perfect medium-sized companion for a loving family. Whitney‚Äôs journey began alongside her brothers, born to their feral mother, Ferraro. After facing the uncertainty of life in a South Carolina shelter, she was rescued along with her siblings just before a tragic fate could befall them. Though she may be a bit nervous in new situations, Whitney‚Äôs sweet nature allows her to warm up quickly to those who show her kindness and patience. Whitney‚Äôs personality truly shines when she is around her brothers, who help bring out her playful side and encourage her to explore her surroundings. We believe that Whitney would thrive best in a home with another dog, as having a furry companion to guide her would help her build confidence and trust in her humans. This affectionate girl loves to snuggle and relax, and she hopes to find a family that will appreciate her gentle spirit and provide her with the love and support she needs to flourish. If you‚Äôre looking for a sweet and patient companion who will bring joy and comfort to your life, Whitney is the perfect pup for you!

Name: Rick
Description: ‚ú® Meet Rick ‚ú® This 3.5-month-old lab mix is the total package ‚Äî sweet, playful, and full of love üêæüíõ Rick does great with other animals (including cats üê±) and absolutely adores children. Name: Buddy
Description: Meet Sweet Almost 3-Year-Old Spaniel!** Introducing our delightful almost 3-year-old spaniel, a loving companion who brings joy to everyone he meets! Despite some physical challenges, including a narrow space between the disks in his back and tenderness in his hips, he never lets that get in the way of his playful spirit. With the help of carprofen, he stays comfortable and ready to explore his surroundings. Our boy has a playful personality and is great with cats, dogs, and kids alike, making him the perfect addition to any family. His foster has found creative solutions to support him, like a diaper and belly band, which allow him to thrive in his loving environment. While he may sometimes have accidents while walking and gets a little too excited, his sweet demeanor and affectionate nature easily win over hearts. He is ready to find his forever home, where he can share his love and receive the care he deserves. Will you be the one to give him a second chance? We need a foster by commitment by tonight for Saturday/sunday !***

Name: Asher
Description: Asher is the sweetest big boy with a shy heart and a goofy spirit waiting to shine! Once he feels safe, his tail starts wagging, his personality blossoms ‚Äî and he‚Äôll melt right into your lap (even though he doesn‚Äôt quite realize his size üòÇ). üåü What Makes Asher Special: ‚Ä¢ Shy at first, but bonds beautifully with gentle people ‚Ä¢ Good with cats and other dogs ‚Äî respectful & friendly ‚Ä¢ Enjoys walks in the city and exploring new places ‚Ä¢ Food-motivated ‚Äî great for continued training ‚Ä¢ Still growing‚Ä¶ those big paws are going to be impressive! ‚Ä¢ Might borrow his sister‚Äôs snacks if you‚Äôre not watching üëÄüíõ üè° Home Skills: ‚Ä¢ Sleeps quietly in his crate from 10 PM ‚Äì 7/8 AM ‚Ä¢ Only a few overnight accidents ‚Äî learning quickly ‚Ä¢ Working on potty training + uses puppy pads ‚Ä¢ Gets along well with dogs of all sizes & personalities Asher would thrive in a patient, loving home that can help him build confidence and continue his training. He‚Äôs a gentle, smushy, city-ready puppy who just wants to feel safe and loved ‚Äî and he‚Äôll give it right back tenfold. üíõ

Name: Princess
Description: üíó Meet Princess ‚Äì A Heart Too Big for the Pain She‚Äôs Known üíó Princess‚Äôs story is one that truly touches the soul. This beautiful 6-month-old Pitbull mix was rescued back in August by a kind man who adored her deeply. He found her when she needed someone most ‚Äî scared, unwanted, and alone ‚Äî and he gave her safety, love, and a name fit for her sweet spirit: Princess. Tragically, her rescuer passed away not long after saving her. üíî Through heartbreak and loss, one thing remained clear ‚Äî Princess meant the world to him, and he wanted her to have a happy life. After his passing, a compassionate neighbor stepped in to make sure Princess wouldn‚Äôt end up back on the streets. She‚Äôs been caring for her and reaching out for help to find the forever home her rescuer always dreamed of for her. Princess is everything her name promises ‚Äî gentle, loyal, affectionate, and eager to please. She‚Äôs still very young, learning the world around her, and deserves a patient family who will continue to guide her with love. She‚Äôs dog-friendly with the right introductions and adores human companionship ‚Äî all she wants is to belong.

Name: Claira

Name: Juicy Fruit

Name: Alderly (Al)
Description: Put Short Bio here: Alderly (we call him Larry) is the most loving and kind pup I've ever had the pleasure of spending time with. He is perfectly house trained and kind and gentle to all. He is the biggest snuggle bug with his favorite people. He's equally happy to spend the whole day cuddling in bed or exploring the nieghborhood. He really is the best boy in the world and would be the perfect edition to any family. This dog is truly a blessing and has shown me so much love, he is so easy to fall in love iwth and watching him grow into the more confident happy pup he is now has been a privilege. Fill out all below: Personality & Characteristics: Snuggliest guy ever to his mom, but a little more hesitant to open up fully to others - always is polite and gentle. Curious and adorable walk compainion, never pulls on leash, just excited to sniff around and hang out with me. My foster dog is good with: Dogs, Kids, Cats My foster dog is: House trained 3 Keywords for your pup: SNUGGLER, loyal, patient Energy Level (1= calm, 10= high energy): 5 Barker? Or Quiet Pup?: very quiet boy, sometimes will cry of excitement when I get home after a while Walking Manners: Perfect manners, just occasionally a little bit nervous around loud motercycles, tall men, and big cars Appetite: Perfectly normal Favorite Things: Snuggles (/whoever is his favorite person), walks, bullysticks/greenies,!his farmers dog food, Commands/Tricks: very good with stay/come/yes/no type commands but no tricks up his sleeve quite yet - I'm sure he'll be a fast learner ALL adoptions require a completed application and final contract. The application can be found at WaldosRescue.org and once you are approved to adopt you will be put in touch with the foster to see if it‚Äôs a good match. We are a RESCUE not a shelter. We conduct veterinary and personal reference checks during the application approval process. We are unable to contact every applicant for every dog. We will select the best applicant for each dog, based on the dogs needs. Waldos Rescue Pen is a 501c3 whose primary focus is rescuing dogs from the euthanasia list from high kill shelters throughout the United States and Korea.

Name: Red
Description: Red - 4 years, 12lbs, Chiweenie, Spayed Our Team Says: Red would do best in a home with another dog. She came from a hoarding situation and is much more confident around another dog. This dog is eligible to join our foster-to-adopt program. Please email fostertoadopt@socialteesnyc.org with the animal‚Äôs name in the subject line if you are interested! Want to straight up adopt? Submit an adoption application a t socialteesnyc.org Level of dog ownership experience needed: BEGINNER: This means we predict this dog will be low on the challenge scale due to its breed/age combo. Potentially a good fit for someone who has relevant dog care experience (fostering, dog sitting) and is looking to adopt their first pup. Energy level MEDIUM: Needs a daily 60-90 minute walk or window of quick paced exercise (minimum) in addition to potty break strolls (10-30 min each). Also needs significant socializing opportunities outside the home and mental stimulation at home like tricks training practice, chew items, and puzzle toys. (This is regardless of dog size ‚Äì many small breeds were designed for lots of activity and will exhibit unwanted behavior when they‚Äôre understimulated.) Okay in the city? We don‚Äôt know yet. Most adult dogs do well in the city after they‚Äôve had time to adjust to a new environment, but some never adapt and need homes in the burbs. Potty trained? Probably! Adults usually are, but all will have transitional accidents for the first week or so. A consistent walking route and schedule plus finding spots with grass or dirt can help. Social with other dogs? Yes, but we don‚Äôt know to what degree yet. Some like to wrestle with every passing pup, others can coexist well but prefer to keep to themselves. We‚Äôll learn more soon. Social with cats? Not sure yet! Some breed mixes that are generally NOT great matches for homes with cats include large hounds, huskies, and shepherds. Comfortable with children? (ALWAYS requires adult supervision) We‚Äôre not sure yet, but we try to err on the side of caution. Respectful kids ages 8 and up are probably a safe bet. Children must always be monitored and taught to interact with dogs of any age respectfully. Medical status Healthy as far as we know. Up to date on their DHPP, Bordetella, and Rabies vaccines; heartworm tested if coming from the South or Puerto Rico ; spayed/neutered; microchipped; treated with dewormer upon intake How this dog ended up with Social Tees: Most of our dogs come via partner groups who help us save them from shelters where they are at risk of euthanasia in Tennessee, Los Angeles and Puerto Rico. There are very few spay/neuter resources there and many more animals in those areas than there are people to adopt them. Rescue groups like ours bring them to the northeast where the desire for pets like these allows us to save their lives. PLEASE NOTE: We cannot guarantee any breed mix, exact age, or full grown size (if the dog is under a year old). We do our best with very educated guesses though! This animal is not at the Social Tees office, all are in foster homes. LEARN MORE ABOUT US: socialteesnyc.org and Instagram @socialteesnyc

Name: Lissa
Description: Lissa - 1 yr, 35 lbs, Beagle/Lab Mix, Spayed This dog is eligible to join our foster-to-adopt program. Please email fostertoadopt@socialteesnyc.org with the animal‚Äôs name in the subject line if you are interested! Want to straight up adopt? Submit an adoption application at socialteesnyc.org. Our Team Says: "Lissa is a very easy, chill and well behaved dog to have around. A perfect buddy. She would do best in a calm part of the city - BK, Queens or the calm areas near Central Park. She'd be beyond thrilled to live in the burbs. She's very trusting of women but takes some time to warm up to men, so they need to be extra gentle and patient with her." Thier Foster Parent Says: " Lissa is such a sweet girl. She loves attention - pets, belly rubs, even just talking to her. She loves to play fetch in the house with her stuffed toys and especially the tennis ball. She likes to play bite but is super gentle and listens when told to be nice or to stop. She knows sit, down, paw, other paw, and two paws (two paws meet two hands) - loves treats so can only do so many of those tricks before she gets too excited. Lissa loves to be outside and sniff but can be wary of noisier streets. Garbage trucks and mopeds/motorcycles seem to bother her the most. I think she would love a yard, and/or a quiet neighborhood to get longer walks in or near a park. If we go earlier in the morning when it is quiet, she walks very well. Easy to handle on the leash, sometimes just needs a little extra encouragement to keep walking if she gets spooked. Completely potty trained. We go out in the morning before breakfast, 1-2 times during the day, and once more before bedtime. Even though she doesn't walk too much, she's still pretty chill in the apartment. She'll sleep, seek out attention throughout the day to play for a bit and get out some energy, but ultimately hangs on the couch and just likes to be near someone. Loves attention but is just fine left alone - always greets you like you've been gone for ages and it is the sweetest welcome home. I adore her! She is very easy to take care of and is such a lover. Genuinely surprised someone hasn't adopted her yet!" Level of dog ownership experience needed: INTERMEDIATE: This dog will need significant structure and plenty of daily exercise, training, and mental stimulation ‚Äì 90 consecutive minutes of movement in the morning plus potty break walks and brain games throughout the day. The adopter must have relevant primary care experience with a similar breed, temperament, and/or energy level. (Primary care experience includes ownership, fostering, or dog sitting as an adult, not a dog you grew up with.) MEDIUM: Needs a daily 60-90 minute walk or window of quick paced exercise (minimum) in addition to potty break strolls (10-30 min each). Also needs significant socializing opportunities outside the home and mental stimulation at home like tricks training practice, chew items, and puzzle toys. (This is regardless of dog size ‚Äì many small breeds were designed for lots of activity and will exhibit unwanted behavior when they‚Äôre understimulated.) Potty trained? Probably! Adults usually are, but all will have transitional accidents for the first week or so. A consistent walking route and schedule plus finding spots with grass or dirt can help. Social with other dogs? Yes, but we don‚Äôt know to what degree yet. Some like to wrestle with every passing pup, others can coexist well but prefer to keep to themselves. We‚Äôll learn more soon. Social with cats? Not sure yet! Some breed mixes that are generally NOT great matches for homes with cats include large hounds, huskies, and shepherds. Comfortable with children? (ALWAYS requires adult supervision) We‚Äôre not sure yet, but we try to err on the side of caution. Respectful kids ages 8 and up are probably a safe bet. Children must always be monitored and taught to interact with dogs of any age respectfully. Okay in the city? We don‚Äôt know yet. Most adult dogs do well in the city after they‚Äôve had time to adjust to a new environment, but some never adapt and need homes in the burbs. Medical status Healthy as far as we know. Up to date on their DHPP, Bordetella, and Rabies vaccines; heartworm negative; spayed/neutered; microchipped; treated with dewormer upon intake How this dog ended up with Social Tees: Most of our dogs come via partner groups who help us save them from shelters where they are at risk of euthanasia in Tennessee, Puerto Rico or Southern California. There are very few spay/neuter resources there and many more animals in those areas than there are people to adopt them. Rescue groups like ours bring them to the northeast where the desire for pets like these allows us to save their lives. PLEASE NOTE: We cannot guarantee any breed mix, exact age, or full grown size (if the dog is under a year old). We do our best with very educated guesses though! This animal is not at the Social Tees office, all are in foster homes. LEARN MORE ABOUT US: socialteesnyc.org and Instagram @socialteesnyc PLEASE NOTE: This animal is not at the Social Tees office ‚Äî all of our dogs and cats are in foster homes while they wait to find their forever families. :) If you‚Äôd like to apply to adopt this pet, please complete an adoption application at socialteesnyc.org. Because we are a small team and receive hundreds of applications each week, we are unable to respond to every application and every inquiry email, but we do our best. Please have patience! If your application is approved, you will for sure hear from us. If you have questions, please take a look at the Adoption and Fostering FAQs etc. on our website as all common questions are answered there. Thank you for your understanding and flexibility as we work to save these innocent lives!! LEARN MORE ABOUT US: socialteesnyc.org; Instagram via @socialteesnyc; Facebook.com/socialteesanimalrescue

Name: Ladybug
Description: Ladybug - 10 years, 12lbs, Chi Mix, Spayed This senior angel is eligible to join our foster-to-adopt program. Please email fostertoadopt@socialteesnyc.org with the animal‚Äôs name in the subject line if you are interested! Want to straight up adopt? Submit an adoption application a t socialteesnyc.org Level of dog ownership experience needed: FLEXIBLE: We predict this dog will be low on the challenge scale with regard to exercise and mental stimulation requirements, but seniors tend to need a lot of help and understanding when it comes to lifestyle and veterinary issues. Seniors usually need quiet, calm environments and routines and do not do well with a lot of bustle, change, and rambunctious movement (kids and young playful dogs, for instance). This dog‚Äôs adopter will need to be prepared for senior health challenges, which usually come with expensive veterinary bills and time in vet offices. Senior care can also take an emotional toll on their humans. Adopting a mature pup is a wonderful thing to do, but it can also be difficult. Energy level LOWER: Pretty chill indoors and won‚Äôt demand endless amounts of stimulation and exercise but still needs a few short walks a day (10-30 min each) for potty breaks and to stretch their legs MEDIUM: Needs a daily 60-90 minute walk in addition to potty break strolls (10-30 min each). Also needs socializing opportunities outside the home and a little mental stimulation at home like tricks training practice or chew items. Okay in the city? We don‚Äôt know yet. Most seniors do well in the city after they‚Äôve had time to adjust to a new environment, but some never adapt and need homes in the burbs. Potty trained? Probably! Seniors usually are, but all will have transitional accidents for the first week or so. Seniors tend to need potty breaks more often than younger dogs though, and they can lose their ability to fully control their potty habits as they continue to age, so willingness to be flexible with cleanup and wee pads if necessary is important. Social with other dogs? Yes, but we don‚Äôt know to what degree yet. Some enjoy the company of other calm dogs, others can coexist well but prefer to keep to themselves. We‚Äôll learn more soon. Social with cats? Probably. Seniors are usually mellow enough that they are able to coexist well with cats. Comfortable with children? (ALWAYS requires adult supervision) We‚Äôre not sure yet, but we try to err on the side of caution. Respectful kids ages 8 and up are probably a safe bet. Children must always be monitored and taught to interact with dogs of any age respectfully. Medical status Healthy as far as we know. Up to date on their DHPP, Bordetella, and Rabies vaccines; heartworm tested if coming from the South or Puerto Rico; spayed/neutered; microchipped; treated with dewormer upon intake. Adopters will need to be ready for senior care ‚Äì at a minimum, that will be annual checkups including senior bloodwork and a dental post adoption (most senior rescues need one). How this dog ended up with Social Tees: Most of our dogs come via partner groups who help us save them from shelters where they are at risk of euthanasia in Tennessee, Los Angeles and Puerto Rico. There are very few spay/neuter resources there and many more animals in those areas than there are people to adopt them. Rescue groups like ours bring them to the northeast where the desire for pets like these allows us to save their lives. PLEASE NOTE: We cannot guarantee any breed mix, exact age, or full grown size (if the dog is under a year old). We do our best with very educated guesses though! This animal is not at the Social Tees office, all are in foster homes. LEARN MORE ABOUT US: socialteesnyc.org and Instagram @socialteesnyc

Name: Pongo
Description: Pongo - 6 months & 35lbs (as of 10/21), Poodle Mix, Neutered Estimated full grown size around 50lbs This puppy is eligible to join our foster-to-adopt program. Please email fostertoadopt@socialteesnyc.org with the animal‚Äôs name in the subject line if you are interested! Want to straight up adopt? Submit an adoption application a t socialteesnyc.org Our Team Says: Pongo does best in the calmer parts of the city - BK, Queens, etc. Would love a burbs home. Thier Foster Parent Says: ‚ÄúPerfect Pongo‚Äù is our nickname for this goofy and cuddly guy. He‚Äôs an absolute love bug and can‚Äôt get enough of cuddles, especially in the morning when he‚Äôs lazy and wants to sleep in. We‚Äôve been working on crate training and he has no aversion to the crate‚Äîhe‚Äôd prefer to sit with you on the couch, but on occasion he has put himself to bed in the crate. He now knows how to ‚Äúsit‚Äù and ‚Äúcome‚Äù, both of which are super helpful in walks when the city can become a little overstimulating for this Southern Gentleman. On walks he‚Äôs getting better on the leash, although he does love trash bags, probably a survival tactic from his previous days. He‚Äôs truly the nicest and kindest dog, with a heart of gold. He‚Äôs also incredibly enthusiastic, which can be both good and bad on walks. He loves to play with other dogs, sometimes playing for him is using his big paws to bat at another pup. He can be skittish around loud noises and big trucks. His potty training is going well! He does prefer to pee inside on a puppy pad, but he hasn‚Äôt had an accident off the puppy pad since his first day. He is a puppy so he might try to put his mouth around your finger, but he never closes on it. He‚Äôs got a soft mouth and the best heart." Level of dog ownership experience needed: INTERMEDIATE: As an adult, this dog will need significant structure and plenty of daily exercise, training, and mental stimulation ‚Äì 90 consecutive minutes of movement in the morning plus potty break walks and brain games throughout the day. The adopter must have relevant primary care experience with a similar breed, temperament, and/or energy level. (Primary care experience includes ownership, fostering, or dog sitting as an adult, not a dog you grew up with.) Relevant puppy care experience is a huge plus, but bare minimum the adopter must have TONS of time and patience. Raising a puppy can be a lot of fun, but it‚Äôs also tremendous work. Puppies‚Äô personalities and exercise/stimulation requirements change dramatically between now and when they‚Äôre a year old as their bodies and brains develop, so an active lifestyle and the ability to adapt to a pup‚Äôs evolving needs are a must. We strongly urge professional dog training with a rewards based trainer from the get go. Adults only or kids ages 8 and up ‚Äì all puppies go through a mouthy, rambunctious phase and often accidentally hurt children when playing. PLEASE DO YOUR OWN BREED RESEARCH to make sure you have a better understanding of the kind of temperament and exercise requirements this dog may have as an adult. Energy level MEDIUM: Very young puppies sleep and nap a lot, but their energy level skyrockets when they become teens (4 months to around a year). As an adult, this dog will need significant structure and plenty of daily exercise, training, and mental stimulation ‚Äì 90 consecutive minutes of movement in the morning plus potty break walks and brain games throughout the day at a minimum. (This is regardless of dog size ‚Äì many small breeds were designed for lots of activity and will exhibit unwanted behavior when they‚Äôre understimulated.) TOLERANCE TO CITY Adjusting to the city ‚Äì Spooked easily by loud noises and bustling areas but walks pretty well in quiet areas and probably just needs more time to adjust (may be a puppy or a brand new rescue). Would prefer a home in a calmer part of the city or the suburbs. POTTY TRAINING Sort of ‚Äî On the way and learning! May be using wee pads (is a puppy or a brand new rescue) COMFORT LEVEL WITH STRANGERS Social butterfly ‚Äì Wants to be friends with everyone who walks by, loves anyone who will stop to say hello. (But also a little shy some days) BEHAVIOR WITH CHILDREN (always requires adult supervision) Yes for most ages ‚Äì very confident, gentle, low energy, tolerant, not mouthy (Can get scared when kids are erratic or aggressively patting his head) SOCIAL BEHAVIOR WITH OTHER DOGS Yes ‚Äì Good with most other dogs (sizes, breeds, etc.) as far as we know and enjoys socializing with other canines RESPECTFUL BEHAVIOR WITH OTHER ANIMALS (cats, small pets, etc.) Not sure ‚Äì Wants to chase squirrels and birds so may not be a good match for a home with cats, rabbits, etc. MOUTHY BEHAVIOR Needs training ‚Äì Is either still in the puppy stage or was never trained. Tries to put their mouth on your hands when playing or needs attention, grabs leash, chews on your personal belongings SEPARATION ANXIETY Adjusting ‚Äì Might cry for a few minutes when you first leave the house but settles pretty quickly and has no problem being left alone otherwise. LEASH MANNERS WTF is a leash ‚Äì Pulls hard. Zig zags like crazy. Has no idea how to walk on a leash or doesn‚Äôt have outside privileges yet (too young) CUDDLE BUG LEVEL High ‚Äì Wants to be in your lap pretty much all the time JUMPING ON PEOPLE TO SAY HELLO Listens to correction ‚Äì Only jumps on people they know when really excited, stops with correction. CRATE TRAINING Yep/mostly ‚Äì Seems comfortable in the crate, may whine a little at first but settles pretty quickly. We use the crate when we leave the pup alone and/or at night. MEDICAL STATUS: Healthy as far as we know. Up to date on their DHPP and Bordetella vaccines (for dogs under 4 months old, adopters will need to finish the DHPP vaccine series and administer the Rabies vaccine at 16 weeks of age), spayed/neutered; microchipped; treated with dewormer upon HOW DID THIS DOG END UP WITH US? Most of our dogs come via partner groups who help us save them from shelters where they are at risk of euthanasia in Tennessee, Los Angeles and Puerto Rico. There are very few spay/neuter resources there and many more animals in those areas than there are people to adopt them. Rescue groups like ours bring them to the northeast where the desire for pets like these allows us to save their lives. PLEASE NOTE: We cannot guarantee any breed mix, exact age, or full grown size (if the dog is under a year old). We do our best with very educated guesses though! This animal is not at the Social Tees office, all are in foster homes. LEARN MORE ABOUT US: socialteesnyc.org and Instagram @socialteesnyc

Name: Holiday
Description: Holiday - 5 months, 15lbs, Terrier/Pom Mix, Spayed Expected full grown size 25lbs This puppy is eligible to join our foster-to-adopt program. Please email fostertoadopt@socialteesnyc.org with the animal‚Äôs name in the subject line if you are interested! Want to straight up adopt? Submit an adoption application a t socialteesnyc.org Level of dog ownership experience needed: INTERMEDIATE: As an adult, this dog will need significant structure and plenty of daily exercise, training, and mental stimulation ‚Äì 90 consecutive minutes of movement in the morning plus potty break walks and brain games throughout the day. The adopter must have relevant primary care experience with a similar breed, temperament, and/or energy level. (Primary care experience includes ownership, fostering, or dog sitting as an adult, not a dog you grew up with.) Relevant puppy care experience is a huge plus, but bare minimum the adopter must have TONS of time and patience. Raising a puppy can be a lot of fun, but it‚Äôs also tremendous work. Puppies‚Äô personalities and exercise/stimulation requirements change dramatically between now and when they‚Äôre a year old as their bodies and brains develop, so an active lifestyle and the ability to adapt to a pup‚Äôs evolving needs are a must. We strongly urge professional dog training with a rewards based trainer from the get go. Adults only or kids ages 8 and up ‚Äì all puppies go through a mouthy, rambunctious phase and often accidentally hurt children when playing. PLEASE DO YOUR OWN BREED RESEARCH to make sure you have a better understanding of the kind of temperament and exercise requirements this dog may have as an adult. Energy level MEDIUM: Very young puppies sleep and nap a lot, but their energy level skyrockets when they become teens (4 months to around a year). As an adult, this dog will need significant structure and plenty of daily exercise, training, and mental stimulation ‚Äì 90 consecutive minutes of movement in the morning plus potty break walks and brain games throughout the day at a minimum. (This is regardless of dog size ‚Äì many small breeds were designed for lots of activity and will exhibit unwanted behavior when they‚Äôre understimulated.) POTTY TRAINED? Working on this skill. Puppies under 12 weeks old are often on track with their wee pad skills, but they‚Äôre too young to walk outside in public NYC areas yet because they haven‚Äôt finished their puppy vaccine series. Puppies older than 12 weeks are usually learning to do their business outside. Potty training takes a lot of patience, consistency, and clean up. SOCIAL WITH DOGS? Yes. Some puppies are shy, others are bold, but all have the potential to be taught healthy socializing skills. It‚Äôs a huge part of raising a puppy and must be done carefully. How they interact with other dogs depends largely on how their humans help them learn to. SOCIAL WITH CHILDREN? (ALWAYS requires adult supervision) Yes‚Ä¶ but most puppies are not a great match for a home with kids under age 8 because they go through intense mouthy play and rambunctious phases and often accidentally hurt young kids while playing. Children must always be monitored and taught to interact with dogs of any age respectfully. SOCIAL WITH CATS? Yes. Almost all puppies have the potential to be friends with a cat. It‚Äôs on the adopter to know their cat‚Äôs temperament and preferences and to teach their puppy respectful manners. MOUTHY PLAY: High! All puppies go through phases where they chew your stuff and grab your hands, arms, feet‚Ä¶ puppies naturally explore the world, play, and test boundaries with their mouths. (It also happens when they‚Äôre teething.) Their teeth are super sharp though, so it can be a very painful phase for humans and other animals in the home. Proper training, outlets, and socialization are key. SEPARATION ANXIETY MEDIUM: Most puppies have some level of separation anxiety as they learn to self soothe. Often they cry the first 10+ minutes when they are left home alone or in a crate. Consistent training and alone time is crucial. LEASH MANNERS: None. :) Will need to learn this skill. CRATE TRAINED: Nope. None of our new puppies have been formally trained, but many of our foster parents/adopters choose to crate train. It can be a great way to keep puppies safe and teach them independence. MEDICAL STATUS: Healthy as far as we know. Up to date on their DHPP and Bordetella vaccines (for dogs under 4 months old, adopters will need to finish the DHPP vaccine series and administer the Rabies vaccine at 16 weeks of age), spayed/neutered; microchipped; treated with dewormer upon HOW DID THIS DOG END UP WITH US? Most of our dogs come via partner groups who help us save them from shelters where they are at risk of euthanasia in Tennessee, Los Angeles and Puerto Rico. There are very few spay/neuter resources there and many more animals in those areas than there are people to adopt them. Rescue groups like ours bring them to the northeast where the desire for pets like these allows us to save their lives. PLEASE NOTE: We cannot guarantee any breed mix, exact age, or full grown size (if the dog is under a year old). We do our best with very educated guesses though! This animal is not at the Social Tees office, all are in foster homes. LEARN MORE ABOUT US: socialteesnyc.org and Instagram @socialteesnyc

Name: Lio
Description: Lio - 10 years, 14lbs, Shi-poo, Neutered This senior angel is eligible to join our foster-to-adopt program. Please email fostertoadopt@socialteesnyc.org with the animal‚Äôs name in the subject line if you are interested! Want to straight up adopt? Submit an adoption application a t socialteesnyc.org Our Team Says: "Lio has missing fur on the bottom half of his body due to living in neglect for a long time. He was rescued with a few other dogs thier hair grew back but his has not and we're not sure if it will - he's seen a vet - good bloodkwork for a senior. Lio also needs a home with another dog - he has seperation anxiety and another dog helps him a ton." Thier Foster Parent Says: " Lio has the sweetest, warmest personality and is always eager to please. He loves toys and can happily entertain himself, but he lights up when you join in on the fun. A true cuddle bug, he adores napping nearby and snuggling close. He‚Äôs still learning to go potty outside ‚Äî we‚Äôve been practicing every day by going on walks and letting him explore where other dogs have gone, but he hasn‚Äôt quite made the connection yet. He does use pee pads indoors and we‚Äôre continuing to work on it with patience and routine. On walks, I‚Äôve already noticed steady improvement with his leash skills ‚Äî he‚Äôs becoming more confident, curious, and comfortable with each outing. He‚Äôs been wonderful with other dogs, greeting them gently and respectfully, and while he‚Äôs a little shy in busier settings, he warms to people with a little bit of time. Despite being a senior, Lio has great energy ‚Äî he can match your pace, whether you‚Äôre on a Zoom call needing a calm companion or ready for playtime. He's working hard on being home alone - his ideal home has another dog in it - he came from a hoarding situation. Occasionally, he‚Äôll nudge a toy your way, just to see if you‚Äôre up for a little play or some extra pet." This dog‚Äôs adopter will need to be prepared for senior health challenges, which usually come with expensive veterinary bills and time in vet offices. Senior care can also take an emotional toll on their humans. Adopting a mature pup is a wonderful thing to do, but it can also be difficult. TOLERANCE TO CITY City pup ‚Äì Seems unfazed by the sights and sounds, may as well have been born here. POTTY TRAINING Sort of ‚Äî On the way and learning! May be using wee pads (is a puppy or a brand new rescue) COMFORT LEVEL WITH STRANGERS In between bean ‚Äì Fine with meeting new people but not particularly interested, kind of shy in busy social situations like a gathering or a packed day in the park. BEHAVIOR WITH CHILDREN (always requires adult supervision) Yes for most ages ‚Äì very confident, gentle, low energy, tolerant, not mouthy SOCIAL BEHAVIOR WITH OTHER DOGS Yes ‚Äì Good with most other dogs (sizes, breeds, etc.) as far as we know and enjoys socializing with other canines RESPECTFUL BEHAVIOR WITH OTHER ANIMALS (cats, small pets, etc.) Not sure ‚Äì Wants to chase squirrels and birds so may not be a good match for a home with cats, rabbits, etc. Have not really seen him around other animals besides dogs. Does not chase squirrels so far. MOUTHY BEHAVIOR Working on it ‚Äì Is respectful of hands, feet, etc. but likes to chew on things they‚Äôre not supposed to like shoes, furniture, etc. Want to note that this is very minimal and he will stop if you just ask him to. SEPARATION ANXIETY (Please leave your foster dog home alone every day for at least 20 minutes.) Adjusting ‚Äì Might cry for a few minutes when you first leave the house but settles pretty quickly and has no problem being left alone otherwise. Seems to adjust being left alone a little better out of a crate than in a crate. Slightly anxious. LEASH MANNERS Getting the hang of it ‚Äì Probably hasn‚Äôt been on a leash much in their life but figuring it out. Might be a mild puller but responds to correction. CUDDLE BUG LEVEL High ‚Äì Wants to be in your lap pretty much all the time JUMPING ON PEOPLE TO SAY HELLO Listens to correction ‚Äì Only jumps on people they know when really excited, stops with correction. CRATE TRAINING Working on it ‚Äì We set one up and leave the door open but rarely close it because the dog freaks out Medical status Healthy as far as we know. Name: Odie
Description: Odie - 1 year, 33lbs, Aussie Mix, Neutered This dog is eligible to join our foster-to-adopt program. Please email fostertoadopt@socialteesnyc.org with the animal‚Äôs name in the subject line if you are interested! Want to straight up adopt? Submit an adoption application a t socialteesnyc.org Thier Foster Parent Says: "In less than 12 hours Odie has quickly decided that he‚Äôs a city guy. He is a showstopper on the streets rocking his silky coat and middle part. He is pretty unphased by city life and loves to go for a long walk or accompany you on your errands. He enjoys saying hello to other dogs on the street and will try to jump up and say hi to strangers at times. He is quickly getting the hang of leash walking and does all his business outside- in a day or two he‚Äôll be a pro at the leash. He is extremely affectionate and will climb into your lap gently for cuddles and lick your whole face clean. He loves to be pet, but prefers to find a cozy spot on the carpet or dog bed to nap. At home he will play with his toys on his own or occupy himself with a chew, while keeping a close eye on you. It honestly doesn‚Äôt get more perfect than this southern gentleman." Level of dog ownership experience needed: INTERMEDIATE: This dog will need significant structure and plenty of daily exercise, training, and mental stimulation ‚Äì 90 consecutive minutes of movement in the morning plus potty break walks and brain games throughout the day. The adopter must have relevant primary care experience with a similar breed, temperament, and/or energy level. (Primary care experience includes ownership, fostering, or dog sitting as an adult, not a dog you grew up with.) Energy level MEDIUM: Needs a daily 60-90 minute walk or window of quick paced exercise (minimum) in addition to potty break strolls (10-30 min each). Also needs significant socializing opportunities outside the home and mental stimulation at home like tricks training practice, chew items, and puzzle toys. (This is regardless of dog size ‚Äì many small breeds were designed for lots of activity and will exhibit unwanted behavior when they‚Äôre understimulated.) Medical status Healthy as far as we know. Up to date on their DHPP, Bordetella, and Rabies vaccines; heartworm tested if coming from the South or Puerto Rico ; spayed/neutered; microchipped; treated with dewormer upon intake How this dog ended up with Social Tees: Most of our dogs come via partner groups who help us save them from shelters where they are at risk of euthanasia in Tennessee, Los Angeles and Puerto Rico. There are very few spay/neuter resources there and many more animals in those areas than there are people to adopt them. Rescue groups like ours bring them to the northeast where the desire for pets like these allows us to save their lives. PLEASE NOTE: We cannot guarantee any breed mix, exact age, or full grown size (if the dog is under a year old). We do our best with very educated guesses though! This animal is not at the Social Tees office, all are in foster homes. LEARN MORE ABOUT US: socialteesnyc.org and Instagram @socialteesnyc
